author: By Remy Tumin
title: These Starfish Face Extinction. Scientists Are Helping Them Mate.
description: Scientists estimate that more than 5 billion sunflower sea stars, once a mighty predator, have died in the Pacific Ocean because of warming waters.
content: Over the past decade, the sunflower sea star has gone from a mighty predator of the Pacific Ocean floor to nearing extinction. The Nature Conservancy estimates that 5.75 billion sunflower sea stars died over the span of three years, a 94 percent global decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Adam Goldman, Edward Wong and Ben Hubbard
title: How Two American Hostages Were Set Free From Gaza
description: It took American and Qatari diplomacy, and self-interested decisions by Hamas, to bring two hostages safely back to Israel.
content: On Oct. 7, a few hours after Hamas began its devastating attack on Israel, Antony J. Blinken, the American secretary of state, spoke by telephone with Qatar’s prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Oct. 14-20
description: A lot of players had nonanswers for this week’s toughest word.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Peace Summit in Egypt Shows a Shift in Rhetoric but no Consensus
description: World leaders met in Cairo on Saturday to talk about de-escalating violence in Gaza. Hours later, they were still deeply divided.
content: Leaders, foreign ministers and diplomats from dozens of Arab, European, African and other countries gathered in Cairo on Saturday for a “peace summit” aimed at de-escalating the violence in Gaza. But after hours of speeches, they had little to show for the trip other than a gaping divide, as Arab leaders castigated Western countries for their silence on Israel’s airstrikes on Palestinian civilians in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: You’re Onto Something
description: Robert Ryan’s Sunday puzzle paints a pretty picture.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: How $17.2 Million in Gold and Cash Disappeared From Toronto’s Airport
description: A lawsuit offers a glimpse into the victim’s view of the April heist, though the case remains unsolved.
content: For six months, the disappearance of $17.2 million in gold bars and cash from a warehouse at Toronto Pearson International Airport has remained a mystery. Now a lawsuit has given the public a glimpse into the victim’s view of the heist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittany Loggins
title: Got a Mouse in Your Apartment? These Scientists Will Take It.
description: A research study is examining how mice that live in cities, close to humans, may have evolved differently from their country cousins.
content: Anna Colliton has lived in her apartment in Pelham Parkway in the Bronx for five years, but she suspects the mice have been there far longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Pulliam Bailey
title: A $96 Million Hindu Temple Opens Amid Accusations of Forced Labor
description: The temple in Robbinsville, N.J., about 15 years in the making, is believed to be the largest in the Western Hemisphere. But its construction has also been clouded in controversy.
content: Hindu pilgrims walked barefoot on the marble floors of the enormous temple, examining intricate stone carvings of deities etched into the ceilings and images of musical instruments and elephants along the white walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers and Vishakha Darbha
title: Silence on Social Media Is Not Complicity
description: What I learned after choosing not to post about the Israel-Hamas war.
content: Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, people have increasingly taken to social media to share their reactions to and outrage over the events unfolding in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Synagogue Leader Is Killed in Detroit, but Motive Is Not Known, Authorities Say
description: Samantha Woll, 40, the president of a synagogue downtown, was lauded as a dynamic figure in the community.
content: The president of a synagogue in Detroit who was known as one of the city’s most vibrant religious leaders was found  killed near her home on Saturday. The authorities have not yet determined a motive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Sarah Kessler
title: How Much Influence Should Universities Give Their Donors?
description: After the Hamas terrorist attack on Israel, some major donors are aiming to shape the free-speech values and top leadership on campuses.
content: Some of the most powerful people in business have taken aim at universities over their responses to the Hamas terrorist attack on Israel and to accusations of antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Ronen Bergman and Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden and Aides Advise Israel to Avoid Widening War With Hezbollah Strike
description: U.S. officials learned that the Israeli defense minister and other military officials supported a pre-emptive strike on Hezbollah. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been cautious.
content: President Biden and his top aides have been urging Israeli leaders against carrying out any major strike against Hezbollah, the powerful militia in Lebanon, that could draw it into the Israel-Hamas war, American and Israeli officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob LeDonne
title: ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ Has Some Surprising Cameos. Here’s a Guide.
description: Musicians, comedians and even a filmmaker make appearances in the epic drama.
content: Throughout his acclaimed filmography, Martin Scorsese has been known for left-of-center casting choices. His longtime collaborator and casting director Ellen Lewis said in an interview that they always “try to go outside the box in interesting ways.” For evidence, consider memorable appearances by Scorsese’s mother, Catherine, in “Goodfellas” and the writer Fran Lebowitz as a judge in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Are Fears of A.I. and Nuclear Apocalypse Keeping You Up? Blame Prometheus.
description: How an ancient Greek myth explains our terrifying modern reality.
content: Prometheus was the Titan who stole fire from the gods of Olympus and gave it to human beings, setting us on a path of glory and disaster and incurring the jealous wrath of Zeus. In the modern world, especially since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, he has served as a symbol of progress and peril, an avatar of both the liberating power of knowledge and the dangers of technological overreach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How an Urban Forager Spends Her Sundays
description: Aly Stoffo knows where to find wild mushrooms, berries and other edible plants on Staten Island. But the location of her favorite paw paw patch is a secret.
content: The urban forager Aly Stoffo leads excursions on Staten Island through her business, Glam Gardener NYC, and is a regular at farmers’ markets across New York and New Jersey, where she sells teas and tinctures made with the plants she harvests. Her Sundays can be chaotic. “They’re jam-packed with hosting workshops and tours or going to events where I’m trying to get people engaged in thinking about the green spaces around them,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Pushing the Body to Extremes to Find Serenity
description: The choreographer Rachid Ouramdane works with acrobats and a highliner in “Corps Extrêmes,” a hypnotic production coming to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
content: Why do some people put their bodies through extreme acts? Why cross the Seine on a wire or climb a mountain during a thunderstorm? The reasons are probably the opposite of what you imagine: Peace. Calm. Serenity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: In Global Conflict Zones, Hospitals and Doctors Are No Longer Spared
description: Over the last two decades, medical facilities and staff have become casualties of war more frequently, in violation of international law.
content: The explosion at the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday was the latest in a growing series of violent incidents involving medical facilities in conflict zones, which together have taken an enormous toll on vital health care infrastructure and staff in violation of what was once a bedrock aspect of international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Vivian Yee
title: First Humanitarian Aid Reaches a Hard-Pressed Gaza
description: But the 20-truck shipment of food, water and medical supplies is only a fraction of what is needed to head off a catastrophe, officials say.
content: After days of diplomatic wrangling, 20 trucks carrying food, water and medical supplies crossed into Gaza on Saturday, providing a ray of hope for the more than two million residents of the enclave, whose living conditions the United Nations called “catastrophic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: It’s Not Just for Throuples Anymore
description: Feeld, the kink- and queer-friendly dating app, has carved out a niche for customers looking for something unusual in potential romantic partners — honesty.
content: When Ana Kirova first heard the idea that she should become chief executive of Feeld, the dating app, she was “terrified.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub, Emily Schmall, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
title: Chapter 1: To Take Control, She Had to Run
description: This is the first part of a series by The Interpreter that examines how, for two young women, chasing opportunity in India has been a fight for their lives.
content: Nasreen Parveen decided to run for her life at the same moment she decided not to end it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: One Partner Runs the Marathon — and the Other Does Everything Else
description: Fifty thousand people are training to run the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5. But they’re not the only ones feeling the burn.
content: Shamyla Khan-Malik was working from home on the Upper West Side last week when her husband came back from an almost two-hour run. “He wanted to talk about his run, to show me the stats, how far he ran, what was his pace, all the splits, his heart rate through the splits, and the elevation and how that impacted the heart rate,” said Ms. Khan-Malik, laughing. “I was doing something a bit more important,” she added. “Like work.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Martin Goetz, Who Received the First Software Patent, Dies at 93
description: “I knew at some point in time the patent office would recognize” computer software, he said. It happened in 1968, helping to ignite the software market.
content: Martin Goetz, who joined the computer industry in its infancy in the mid-1950s as a programmer working on Univac mainframes and who later received the first U.S. patent for software, died on Oct. 10 at his home in Brighton, Mass. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: From Sketch to Runway, the Making of a Bridal Collection
description: The designer Rebecca Schoneveld provides an inside look at how she prepares for New York Bridal Fashion Week.
content: For the last decade or so, the designer Rebecca Schoneveld, who plans to relocate her to studio to Pleasantville, N.Y. next month, has participated in more than a dozen bridal fashion shows, sometimes presenting twice in one year. Although her designs change with each season, her process remains the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Some Contractions
description: Kelly Morenus makes a well-crafted Saturday puzzle debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There are so many neat details in this puzzle, Kelly Morenus’s first construction for The New York Times. The long entry triplets at the top and bottom are imposing but not obscure, almost without exception; the middle of the grid has interesting tidbits everywhere. I think it’s a legitimate Saturday crossword, but one that solves in a smooth, pleasant way, with plenty of clues that kept me on my toes, searching for a second or third option, but no really intractable stumpers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Women Testify That Fashion Mogul Lured Them to ‘Sordid’ Bedroom
description: Five women accusing Peter Nygard of sexual assault completed their testimonies this week as prosecutors prepare to close their case in Toronto.
content: The five women testifying that the Canadian fashion mogul Peter Nygard sexually assaulted them described for jurors over the past four weeks how they ended up in the hidden bedroom suite at his office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Actors and Hollywood Studios to Restart Negotiations
description: Talks aimed at ending the strike by the actors’ union broke up less than two weeks ago, with the two sides saying they remained far apart.
content: The major entertainment studios and the union representing tens of thousands of striking actors will return to the negotiating table on Tuesday, less than two weeks after talks were suspended because the sides remained far apart on significant issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: We Must Not Kill Gazan Children to Try to Protect Israel’s Children
description: If all lives have equal value, why do we treat Palestinian civilians as lesser victims, devalued by association with Hamas terrorism?
content: The crisis in the Middle East is a knotty test of our humanity, asking how to respond to a grotesque provocation for which there is no good remedy. And in this test, we in the West are not doing well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Returning to Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif Aims for a Splashy Comeback
description: After nearly four years in exile, Mr. Sharif, a three-time prime minister, will hold a big gathering before an upcoming election.
content: Nawaz Sharif, a three-time prime minister, planned a grand return to Pakistan on Saturday after years of self-imposed exile, seizing an opening in the country’s turbulent politics and economic disarray to attempt another dramatic comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Markham Heid
title: Even Short Runs Have Major Health Benefits
description: Jogging a mile or two a few times a week can help you live longer and reduce your risk of disease.
content: Running is one of the most popular forms of exercise in America. It may also be one of the healthiest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 21, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 21, 2023.
content: An article on Page 4 this weekend about a Broadway play starring Danny DeVito and his daughter, Lucy DeVito, misstates the title of the audio play that Danny and Lucy DeVito collaborated on. It is “I Think It’s Worth Pointing Out That I’ve Been Very Serious Throughout This Entire Discussion or, Dave and Julia Are Stuck in a Tree,” not “I Think It’s Working Pointing Out…”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: New Evidence Found of Rape and Torture by Russian Forces in Ukraine
description: A U.N. report documented cases in the southern regions of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia, which remain partly under Moscow’s control.
content: A United Nations commission has found new evidence that Russian forces committed war crimes in Ukraine, including deliberate killings, rape and the removal of Ukrainian children, according to a report released on Friday. Victim testimonies also asserted the systematic and widespread use of torture in several Russian detention facilities, the report said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Easy Banana Bread, Butternut Squash Soup and Roasted Fish With Leeks and Salsa Verde
description: Gentle recipes for busy fall weekends.
content: Banana bread is, of course, a treat any time of year. But something about fall makes it feel like peak banana bread season. Maybe it’s because, after a summer of nectarines and peaches and cherries, we turn our attention to the steadfast banana. Maybe it’s because it’s finally cool enough to have the oven running. Or maybe it’s because having kids in the house inevitably means fishing uneaten, freckled brown bananas out of lunchboxes at the end of the day. Whatever the reason, we’re declaring it banana bread season, and celebrating with Lidey Heuck’s aptly named easy banana bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Some Israeli Journalists Express Fear About Conveying Dissenting Views
description: Airing criticism of the country’s response has become even more fraught than in previous conflicts, some journalists and press advocates said.
content: Last weekend, at least a dozen people surrounded the home of a left-wing Israeli commentator who had expressed concern about civilian deaths in Gaza, shouting “traitor” and firing flares in his direction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: American Stories and a British Romance
description: An editor recommends Lorrie Moore’s “Birds of America” and Mary Webb’s “Precious Bane”
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Adam Sella
title: For the Most Vulnerable Hostages, a Plea for Mercy
description: Hamas released two American hostages on Friday, but concern is rising about the hundreds still held in Gaza, especially the injured and ill.
content: Rut Hodaya Perez is in no shape to be held as a hostage in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheldon Pearce
title: Tupac Shakur’s Volatile Life, Delivered by Friendly Hands
description: Access to the late rapper’s journals gives Staci Robinson’s authorized biography a rare intimacy, without delving deeply into his music.
content: Last month, after 27 years, a suspect was charged in the murder of Tupac Shakur. A firecracker and crusader as sharp as he was brusque, Tupac reached megastar status in 1996, when his fourth studio album, “All Eyez on Me,” went five times platinum. Often hailed as one of the greatest rappers of all time, he was a magnet for controversy during his life, and became a martyr for hip-hop militance after his death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Meaney
title: How the World Once Handled War Crimes
description: In “Judgment at Tokyo,” the political scholar Gary J. Bass examines the post-World War II prosecution of Japanese military atrocities and makes the case for the real efficacy of international law.
content: In our age of scorched-earth ground offensives and bombed-out hospitals, the prospect of punishing atrocities perpetrated by governments seems particularly distant. But you could be forgiven for thinking otherwise based on the recent bounty of acclaimed books that glorify the potential of international treaties and tribunals to make lasting peace. Suspicious of diplomatic horse-trading, a prominent segment of Western liberals champion international law as the most promising means to enact their ideal of a just world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Web Summit Chief Steps Down Over Israel Remarks
description: Paddy Cosgrave, the C.E.O. of the tech conference, said he would resign as Alphabet, Meta and Intel joined other companies pulling out of a show next month.
content: The chief executive of Web Summit, one of Europe’s biggest technology conferences, stepped down on Saturday after major sponsors and speakers withdrew from the event, set for next month, following backlash over his public criticism of Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Emerging Radiant Through the Chaos
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 21, 2023.
content: “I was never quite sure what all these critics thought I was supposed to be doing — a Bob Dylan impression?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why We Should Fear China More Than Middle Eastern War
description: A war over Taiwan could end in an outright U.S. loss.
content: On Thursday, Joe Biden gave a speech linking the Israel-Hamas conflict and the Russian invasion of Ukraine and framing American involvement as part of a grand strategy to contain our enemies and rivals. “When terrorists don’t pay a price for their terror, when dictators don’t pay a price for their aggression,” he declared, “they keep going. And the cost and the threats to America and the world keep rising.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo and Robert Jimison
title: Chaos and Frustration Rule as Republicans’ Bitter Speaker Fight Deepens
description: With the House G.O.P. back to square one on electing a new speaker, tempers flared and uncertainty over how the impasse might be resolved only grew.
content: Leaving the House floor shortly after delivering the opening prayer on Friday morning, the House chaplain, Margaret G. Kibben, turned to the sergeant-at-arms flanking the entrance and whispered, “Godspeed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Christian Boone, Dan Simmons, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy
title: Americans, Weary of Foreign Conflicts, Face Another
description: Interviews with voters in key states show that while there is support for Israel and Ukraine, many are torn about how much the U.S. can or should be involved.
content: Since the Hamas attack on Israeli citizens two weeks ago and Israel’s subsequent bombing campaign on Gaza, protesters have flooded American streets. Emotional debates have deeply unsettled Jewish and Palestinian communities here and divided college campuses. Threats against synagogues and mosques have spiked, and a 6-year-old Palestinian-American boy in Chicago was stabbed to death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections Companion, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russians Who Moved to Israel Over One War Are in the Middle of Another One
description: Thousands of citizens with Jewish heritage left for Israel after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Days after Russia invaded Ukraine last year, Matvey Kukuy, a technology entrepreneur, fled the country for Israel, more out of shame than fear. But when Hamas attacked his new home two weeks ago, he did the opposite: While at a conference in Portugal, he booked tickets to go back to Israel in one of its greatest moments of crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Running for Our Lives
description: Very short, slow runs can lead to better health. But that doesn’t lessen the timeless allure of being a “real runner.”
content: Why run? I ask myself this question as I lace up my shoes, as I confront an approaching hill, as I coax one more lap out of my aching calves. The obvious answer is that we run to be healthy, to improve our cardiovascular systems and our moods, to become fitter and stronger. But sometimes it feels like the real reason that I run is to get better at running. I run so that I can run more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Mother in Maine Rallied for Her Son’s Emotional Support Chickens
description: Amy Martin’s son, C-Jay, had struggled with depression and anxiety ever since the pandemic. Maybe chickens could help him. But would city officials let her have a flock at home?
content: Amy Martin stepped to the lectern earlier this month wearing a sweater that said “Mama Bear” and spoke directly to city officials sitting across from her in Bangor, Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Nicholas Nehamas
title: How Ron DeSantis Lost the Internet
description: The G.O.P. contender’s campaign tried to take on Donald Trump’s online army. Now it just wants to end the meme wars.
content: In early May, as Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida prepared to run for president, about a dozen right-wing social media influencers gathered at his pollster’s home for cocktails and a poolside buffet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: ‘I Love You. I Am Sorry’: One Jew, One Muslim and a Friendship Tested by War
description: A Los Angeles program that connects Muslims and Jews has been strained by the war in Israel. But the group’s leaders found that it has strengthened their bond.
content: The two women sat knee to knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Billy Witz
title: How Rich Donors and Loose Rules Are Transforming College Sports
description: A shift that allows booster groups to employ student-athletes has upended the economics of college football and other sports while giving many donors a tax break.
content: The key to recruiting top college football players these days is not just a lavish training facility or a storied coach. It is ensuring the chance for them to hook up with a new type of operation that can pay them eye-popping sums, collected from wealthy boosters who can often write off the donations, for taking on a bit of outside work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: 92NY Pulls Event With Acclaimed Writer Who Criticized Israel
description: The decision to call off an event with the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Viet Thanh Nguyen on Friday drew criticism that the organization was stifling voices it disagrees with.
content: 92NY, one of New York City’s premier cultural venues, decided on Friday to abruptly pull an event that evening featuring the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Viet Thanh Nguyen after he signed an open letter critical of Israel, drawing criticism that the organization was stifling dissenting voices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Ukraine, a Sniper Mission and the Myth of the ‘Good Kill’
description: A New York Times reporter who is a former Marine has a conversation with a Ukrainian sniper about morality in war.
content: What you need to understand about a sniper mission is that from the minute it begins to the minute it ends, everything you do is in service of killing another human being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: I Live in a Subdivided Apartment and My Roommate Refuses to Pay Rent
description: Technically you’re not roommates, but the law could still work in your favor.
content: Q: I recently moved into a room in a three-bedroom apartment in Astoria. Each tenant has a separate lease with the owner, and the tenants are responsible for some utilities, with one roommate paying and the others reimbursing them. When I signed my lease, only one bedroom was occupied. Before I moved in, the landlord moved a tenant from a different unit into the third bedroom in my apartment. This roommate is an alcoholic, hasn’t paid rent for at least six months and has never paid utilities; recently, we’ve had to cover his share. I’ve asked the landlord to serve an eviction notice on this tenant, but she refuses. What rights do I have with respect to making the landlord evict the nonpaying roommate?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: After Bruising Vote, Indigenous Australians Say ‘Reconciliation Is Dead’
description: The rejection of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament is likely to lead to an irreversible shift in the nation’s relationship with its first peoples.
content: The result of the referendum was decisive, and at the same time, divisive. It bruised Indigenous Australians who for decades had hoped that a conciliatory approach would help right the wrongs of the country’s colonial history. So, the nation’s leader made a plea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Murphy
title: How Do You Charge a Friend for a Professional Favor?
description: Despite the adage that friends and money don’t mix, the arrangement can have unique benefits — as long as the boundaries are clear.
content: Eryka Peskin, a friend of mine, recently asked me to look over the language of a webinar she was putting together for her life-coaching business because I am a freelance writer and editor. A few text exchanges soon turned into a lengthy phone call. Mid-conversation, Eryka asked, “Should I be paying you for this?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Rodriguez and Carmilla Floyd
title: Elderly and Imprisoned: ‘I Don’t Count It as Living, Only Existing.’
description: Decades of tough-on-crime sentencing and increasingly rigid release policies have left many to grow old in a system that was not designed to accommodate them.
content: On a clear day in March 2023, the snowy peaks surrounding the California Institution for Men in Chino were visible. Cleveland Lindley stood on a green patch in the prison yard, taking in the view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Path to Reducing Pedestrian Deaths Is Steep but Straight
description: Who or what is to blame for this terrible increase?
content: Last year, according to the Governors Highway Safety Association, more than 7,500 pedestrians were killed while walking on U.S. roadways. Between 2010 and 2021, in fact, pedestrian deaths rose 77 percent, from an annual total of 4,302 to 7,624. These increases represent 40-year-highs for pedestrian fatalities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caster Semenya
title: Running in a Body That’s My Own
description: Athletes like me should get to compete as ourselves.
content: I know I look like a man. I know I sound like a man and maybe even walk like a man and dress like one, too. But I’m not a man; I’m a woman. Playing sports and having muscles and a deep voice make me less feminine, yes. I’m a different kind of woman, I know, but I’m still a woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: After Jordan Falls, House Republicans Ask Who, and What, Is Next
description: A band of more mainstream Republicans brought down the hard-line conservative, but the G.O.P. has hardly stemmed the chaos.
content: Representative Jim Jordan was brought down by the revolt of the rule followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark A. Walsh
title: Bobby Charlton, a Soccer Great, Dies at 86
description: A mainstay of Manchester United and one of the game’s best-loved figures, he won the World Cup in 1966 and the European Cup in 1968.
content: Bobby Charlton, one of soccer’s greatest players, who won the World Cup with England in 1966 in a dazzling career that was tinged by the tragedy of losing eight of his Manchester United teammates in a plane crash at the start of his playing days, died on Saturday. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Jarvis
title: Climate Change Is Keeping Therapists Up at Night
description: How anxiety about the planet’s future is transforming the practice of psychotherapy.
content: Andrew Bryant can still remember when he thought of climate change as primarily a problem of the future. When he heard or read about troubling impacts, he found himself setting them in 2080, a year that, not so coincidentally, would be a century after his own birth. The changing climate, and all the challenges it would bring, were “scary and sad,” he said recently, “but so far in the future that I’d be safe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: DeSantis Says He Would Cancel Student Visas of Hamas Sympathizers
description: At a G.O.P. candidate showcase in Iowa, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and his rivals repeatedly sought to one-up one another on support for Israel.
content: In a competition of hawkish messages on Israel, Ron DeSantis pledged on Friday night to revoke the student visas of Hamas sympathizers if elected president, while Tim Scott said he would withhold Pell grants from universities that failed to stamp out antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Crossings at the U.S. Southern Border Are Higher Than Ever
description: It is the third record-setting year in a row, during a time when migration around the world is at historic highs.
content: Migrants were caught crossing the southern border of the United States more times in the past year than in any other year since at least 1960, when the government started keeping track of the data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Madden
title: Moments in the ‘Buy Nothing’ Life
description: Borrowing the style of Joan Didion’s “The White Album,” a writer considers an online gifting hub where people try to give away unwanted stuff.
content: 1. We post on Buy Nothing in order to give. A frog, kissed just once, could be a prince. A sow’s ear upcycled, a silken satchel. One man’s trash may be another’s “lucky futon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: From Bush v. Gore to ‘Stop the Steal’: Kenneth Chesebro’s Long, Strange Trip
description: Mr. Chesebro, a buttoned-down Harvard lawyer, evolved from left-leaning jurist to key player in the Trump false electors scandal. What happened?
content: In January 2001, Kenneth Chesebro was a mild-mannered Harvard lawyer toiling for Al Gore during the 2000 presidential election recount battle. Two decades later, on Jan. 6, 2021, he joined the mob outside the Capitol, reborn as a MAGA-hatted kingpin.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Growing Old, for Better or Worse
description: Readers, including a 101-year-old woman, react to a guest essay by Roger Rosenblatt about the challenges of aging.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Little Punishment or Change After South Korea’s Halloween Calamity
description: Families of the 159 people crushed to death last year say the government has never acknowledged its mistakes or accepted responsibility.
content: From the beginning, with the grief still raw and anguished questions unanswered, the South Korean government distanced itself from the disaster that unfolded last year on a Halloween weekend in Seoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: 10 Charged in $20 Million Scheme to Sell Black-Market H.I.V. Drugs
description: Federal prosecutors said the defendants encouraged low-income patients to sell their medication to them, then resold the drugs and used the money to buy luxury goods.
content: Federal prosecutors have accused 10 people of orchestrating a $20 million scheme to “get rich” by buying and selling black-market H.I.V. medications that in some cases had been purchased from low-income patients who risked their lives by selling it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ali Stroker Has Tips for Fellow Sleep-Deprived Working Moms
description: The Tony winner and author talked about the Broadway shows she’ll see once she can stay up late again, and the podcast that comforted her during the pandemic.
content: The actress Ali Stroker never thought she would write a book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gershon Baskin
title: I Negotiated Israel’s Hardest Hostage Deal. Here’s What’s Next in Gaza.
description: I have been in touch with leaders of both sides. Prospects remain dim.
content: Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier, had been a hostage for five years before Israel and Hamas were seriously willing to work toward his release. That was 2011. I had been pursuing secret back-channel communications with Hamas since a week after he was captured in a cross-border raid and dragged into Gaza. My partner in these secret negotiations was Ghazi Hamad, Hamas’s spokesman who was then also a political adviser to its prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: The Bear at the End of the Tunnel
description: Stories of people who look hard at what’s ahead of them, and move forward anyway.
content: Stories about people who have a good, long time to think about what they’re doing, look hard at what’s ahead of them, and decide to keep moving forward anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Mike Belleme
title: Seeds of Native Knowledge Grow in North Carolina
description: Countless generations of Cherokee Indians have cultivated lands in the shadow of the Smoky Mountains. More people want to learn from them.
content: There is a mushroom whose beige caps grow wild in the mountains of western North Carolina. When plucked, their broken stems well up with milky droplets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Adam Nagourney
title: Will the Middle East War Change Voters’ Views of Biden?
description: Plagued by low approval ratings, the president has projected himself as a world leader. Strategists warn, however, that his re-election may depend more on domestic issues like the economy.
content: When President Biden addressed the nation from the Oval Office this week, he presented himself as a world leader during a moment of peril amid wars in Ukraine and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chevaz Clarke
title: First Convoy of Aid Enters Gaza Through Rafah Crossing
description: A group of trucks carried much-needed humanitarian supplies into the territory from Egypt on Saturday.
content: A group of trucks carried much-needed humanitarian supplies into the territory from Egypt on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times
